title: Opening
segmentation: Good morning everyone and welcome to Venice and welcome to Simba 2011, the first international workshop similarity based pattern analysis and recognition.
My name is Marcelo Khalilou from University of Venice and I Co. Chaired this worship together with head and Hancock from the University of York.
I will try to spend the next few minutes describing the story behind this workshop.
The background and I will tell you something about this.
Wonderful lecture, whole something about the program and so on and so forth.
So first of all.
Let me say that this workshop marks the end of a European project which is called Simba.
Actually the very same name of this meeting, and actually the very idea of running this workshop we had within the consortium of this project, and we are at the very end of the project.
Actually.
On Friday we are going to have the final review meeting, so actually this workshop marks the very end of this project.
The the name of the the acronym of this project is same but beyond features, similarity based, pattern analysis and recognition and the consortium.
Include myself, University of Venice as the coordinator.
Then we have a group at University of Verona led by Victoria Marino, a group at 80H led by Joachim Blue Man Group at Delft, led by Bob doing Group at York, led by Edwin Hancock and finally.
The group at the Lisbon in Portugal, led by my refrigerator.
So what we try to do with this with this project?
While the idea is already in the title, right?
So we wanted to explore a similarity based approach to pattern recognition and machine learning.
And actually one could well say, well, what's?
You behind this idea because after all, the whole field of pattern recognition and machine learning, they are all based upon the notion of a similarity.
How can I even think of performing a learning problem or a classification problem without any notion of similarity?
So the notion of similarity is really at the heart of any working better recognition and machine learning.
The pine and and this was the starting motivation behind this project.
The point is that the power bag, which is currently dominating the field is actually feature based approach.
I mean the objects to be classified or clustered are described in terms of feature vectors.
This feature vectors represent points in high dimensional space and then the notion of similarity derives usually as from some distance in the in the in the feature space, right?
So this is we thought that this is a very restrictive view because there are many situations actually where it is difficult to describe an object in terms of a feature vector.
Here are a few examples of classical situations when this might happen.
For example, when experts cannot define features in a straightforward way or when they are high dimensional.
Think of images or videos and so on and so forth.
There are many examples here, but probably the most.
A common case where it's difficult to describe objects in terms of feature vectors is the last one, namely, when objects are described in terms of relational structures.
In terms of parts and relations between parts.
Technically these are called graphs or whatever relational structures, and we know it's very difficult to map a graph into a point in high definition space.

So the problem is that when we go beyond the notion of a feature vector, we are in trouble because we probably no longer leave in a convenient Euclidean or metric space, and this of course undermines the very foundations of traditional pattern recognition and machine learning algorithms.
So what we tried to do with this project was to try to bring to full maturation a kind of a paradigm shift.

This lightly emerging in the field where the notion of similarities central and the place is a pivot role, as the notion of feature vector plays in nowadays, techniques in pattern recognition and computer vision machine learning, and.
This is already, you know, if you are aware of the work that that is now, people are now doing pattern recognition and machine learning.
This is clear.
For example, for kernel approach is actually the very notion of a kernel is a notion of similarity.

But still this is a first step toward view where the notion of similarity is important person, because in the traditional approach to kernel methods we still assume the existence of time hidden or implicit high.
High dimensional feature space, right?
Another example is in unsupervised learning where we have a notion of pairwise clustering or in semi supervised learning where we have the notion of graphs transaction.

So, so the whole project actually revolves around 2 main themes which actually correspond to the two fundamental questions that arise when abandoning the notion of a feature vector and relying only on the notion of similarity.
First question is, how can we obtain suitable similarity measures between objects more powerful than feature vectors?
And we focus the spatially in the project on.
On graphs and non relational structures and the other question is, let's suppose that someone has given us some similarity data, some similarity metrics.
How can I use this data in order to perform learning or classification tasks?
So according the accordingly, the structure of the Sigma project is this one.

There is a first thread which was devoted to the problem of deriving similarities for non vectorial data, and here we focused on structural kernels, either a generative or compression or information theoretic kernels and then we focused on the problem of learning and combining similarities.
And then the second thread is to do with the question of how can I use similarity data.
So first of all we tried to characterize the causes and originations of non motricity or non geometry city in similarity data and then we distinguish 2 problems to two situations.
The first one is when the amount of non motricity or non geometry sitting the data is marginal or is not substantial and this allows us to use for example embedded thinkpiece.
And the other situations, where is where?

Instead we have a significant amount of non geometry city in the data, so embedding techniques cannot work by definition, and so we try to apply game theory to attack this particular case where we deal with the original similarity data without trying to do any embedding.
And of course, we also focused on practical real world applications and we had two large scale applications and the first one was done especially by the Group of York in Womans Group at Ath.
The analysis of tissue microarray images of renal cell carcinoma and the second one was done mainly at the University of Verona, with Victoria Marino's group.
The analysis of brain magnetic resonance scans for the diagnosis of mental illnesses.
And in particular, bipolar disorders like schizophrenia.
So if you are interested in what we did in this this the past few years, you can have a look at the workshop at the project website and also.

We are planning to publish a book which will appear most likely in the spring of 2012, which will summarize the achievements we did in this in this project, so it'll be published by Springer and it will appear in the in the series advances in computer vision, pattern recognition.
So much for the project.
Now let's say something about this.
Tacular venue let me say something about this building first, which is called Cuddle Finn.
the Italian translation is Lacasse Dolphin.
the English translation is Dolphins.
How's this building was built in the 16th century by an unknown architect and then in the 17th century in the so in 1621 it was sold to Cardinal Dolphin in Venice for 12,000.
Cool Discord is a currency that was used at that time here in Venice, and that's the reason why this building is called.
Carbon filled.
And then it was parted by several families, cider in Venice or nearby in Milan to the bruiser Lavia Carini and eventually and 19555.
It was purchased by the University of Venice Cafe Oscar University business and for awhile this building have been used as a host for the Applied Mathematics.
Department nowadays is just at the top floor.
We only have administrative offices.
Let me say something about this whole.
This used to be above room actually and from a history of our perspective it's it's really agenda.
We have a ceiling here by Nicola Bambini who lived in the 18th century and you know we are all around the room.
There are 10 big mirrors and actually in that place there were ten tables.
Then expect tackler tables.
And paintings my table.
And now at some point the family who owns this building they run out of money and so they were forced to sell these paintings.
And now you can find them.
A few of them.
You can find that the hermit, Taj and some pietersberg.
If you go there, have a look.
There are two tables which used to be here and if you.
Happened to go to the Met NYC.
There are two more you can see.
Even here.
The border here you can see this border.
Is exactly the border of some of these mirrors.
And 51 is in Vienna, and the Museum of the History of Art.
There are even books written on these paintings.
If you go on Amazon you can buy at least a couple of books on the paintings that used to be here in this ballroom.
OK, so let's say something about the worship now.
So this is the problem of this worship.
We got 35 submissions for this worship.
Actually, there were five more papers.
We got five more papers, but the orders of this paper were not able to provide a final version in time.
So actually with 35, although we got 40 papers and we accept the 16 papers for all our presentation and seven papers for poster presentation.
A few weeks ago I got the request from participant to hang up his own poster during the poster session.
Of course it's not published in the proceedings, so the actual pastors will be 8 just because there will be this extra poster downstairs.
So we will have five oral sessions and we've got three invited talks today will ever recover from Cardiff University, UK tomorrow.
We have Marco Gori from University of Sienna and the last day we have Jon Shave Taylor from UCLA.
Espere so we got video lectures coverage.
See the camera man over there.
I'm pretty sure many of you do know this image very well.
This cameraman picture and I'm sure many of you have done a lot of work in this picture.

So this means that the talks will be video recorded and they would have put on the web in the video lectures web and you need to the speakers have to fill in a consent form and they have to provide these lies afterwards.
Now the interesting part of the meeting is also the social event.
We're going to have a social dinner tomorrow evening in a very nice place next to some marks place and so restaurant LA Caravella.
You've got an invitation ticket in your back, so tomorrow at 8:00 PM.
Love this social dinner.
As far as Atlantis is concerned, they are not included in the registration fee and so we have to have lunch on our own.
There are bunches of restaurants, cafes and bars around in the bag.
We gave you.
You will find a map.
Actually, this map and all these restaurants are critical.
You already know that we got Wi-Fi and you got instructions of how to get Wi-Fi connection here.
And if you have any problems, just ask someone over there, but I'm sure that many of you already know him because of the.
Wi-Fi connection, so let me thank bunch of people who helped us.
Setting up this worship first of all, let me think the product Committee member.
I don't have time to mention all the PC members, but will find this.
The people in these slides and.
Let me also thank the invited speaker so Rica, Handmark, Agori and Jump Ship table for accepting our invitation to give a talk in this workshop.
Let me also thank the local organizing committee, so someone Mikkola Luca in Teresa and also I'm sorry I didn't have a picture of him.
Food cat houses from York University who helped as assembling the proceedings.
And also thanks through our supporters.
First of all, all the people in the symbol consortium and the 7th Framework Program for funding the symbol project, the Pascal to network of excellence for providing support to the meeting.
The APR for sponsoring the workshop and University of Venice.
